docs.lead_paragraph: CHARLES and Jeanne Atchison live near the Cowboy City dance bar on a gravel street in a peeling white and gold mobile home. Weeds sway in the breeze out front. It's a street with a melancholy down-on-one's-luck feel about it. The town is Azle, Tex., a tiny speck on the periphery of Fort Worth. A few years ago, the picture was a far prettier one. Charles (Chuck) Atchison was all set. He made good money - more than $1,000 a week - enough to pay for a cozy house, new cars, fanciful trips. But all that is gone. He's six months behind on rent for his land, and don't even ask about the legal bills. ''It's sort of like I was barreling along and I suddenly shifted into reverse,'' Mr. Atchison said with a rueful smile. ''Well, welcome to whistle blower country.''
